Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Interspecific interactions over a latitudinal resource gradient: a graphical modeling approach using fig wasps
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological interactions between species are often inferred by looking for correlations in abundance between species pairs while disregarding influences of other members of the community. Through the use of computer simulations and available abundance data from a complex insect community (fig wasps), this project will determine the accuracy of a multi-species graphical modeling approach to reveal networks of beneficial and antagonistic ecological interactions among species. After determining the most accurate method of modeling ecological interactions, additional fig-wasp abundance data will be collected from six locations along the Baja Peninsula to test whether or not these interactions, both at the level of species pairs and communities as a whole, are static or dynamic over a large geographic range.

Food webs often rely on predator-prey interactions, and more complete models of ecological networks involving all types of interspecific interactions (including competition, mutualism, and parasitism) are still rare. This project will develop a more inclusive model of ecological communities. The resulting model will also show how the structure of ecological networks is affected by changing environmental conditions, including human-caused habitat fragmentation and global climate change. A graduate student and an undergraduate student will participate in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most organisms are not randomly distributed within their natural environments. Instead, their locations and movement patterns are influenced by both physical features of the environment (e.g., light levels and precipitation) and interactions with other organisms (e.g., prey and predators). These factors can, in turn, affect the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of individual species and entire communities. We used mathematical and computer simulation models to develop theory aimed at predicting how variation in the distributions of organisms in space and time affects the ecology and evolution of species diversity. These models were developed for different types of ecological interactions, including mutualism (mutually beneficial interactions between species), competition (an antagonistic interaction between species), and parasitism (an interaction in which the parasite species benefits at the expense of the host species). A subset of the modeling work was evaluated by testing how well its predictions describe data collected from a wasp community associated with a wild fig species endemic to Baja California, Mexico.

One type of interaction represented by the fig-fig wasp community is a plant-pollinator mutualism in which larvae of the fig-species specific pollinating wasp feed on a subset of the developing fig seeds, as is the case for a number of plant-pollinator mutualisms. We modeled this interaction to see how key properties of this mutualism - pollination efficiency, pollinator production, and seed production - were affected by the spatial distribution of host fig trees across the landscape. We found that when host plants were spatially aggregated (clumped), pollination efficiency and production increased while seed production decreased due to the consumption of developing seeds by larval pollinators. A scattered distribution of host tress, in contrast led to less efficient pollination and lower pollinator production, but a higher production of seeds. We also developed models evaluating how the fig-fig pollinator mutualism was affected by a second non-pollinating wasp species that competes with the pollinating wasp for access to fig seeds. In our model, the non-pollinating competitor was usually able to coexist with the pollinating mutualist when host trees were scattered, only occasionally driving both mutualists (fig and pollinating wasp species) to extinction. In contrast, when host trees were more clumped, the non-pollinator did not drive mutualists to extinction, but were often driven to extinction themselves by competing pollinators.

We also developed and tested theory concerning the coexistence of species competing for resources in ephemeral patches, such as dung, carrion, or fruit. It is surprising that the number of ecologically similar species associated with ephemeral patches is often unusually large because competition among species for a single resource typically results in the extinction of all but the best competitor. Traditionally, explanations for the high observed diversity focused on mechanisms of aggregation: if organisms aggregate with members of their own species more than members of other species, they will lower their own species' competitive ability, allowing other competitor species to persist. We suggest a different, but not mutually exclusive, mechanism to facilitate the coexistence. We show that when organisms experience a trade-off between how much energy they invest in reproduction versus dispersal, multiple competitor species can coexist if they specialize differently in their investment between these traits. We tested to see if this predicted reproduction-dispersal trade-off exists in a community of non-pollinating fig wasps in Baja California.
